Fig. 1 Strategy followed to develop new Mn(I) catalysts based on NHC-phosphine ligands. Fig. 2 Perspective views of complexes 2–6 with thermal ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level. The hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. Fig. 3 Perspective views of complexes 12 and 13 with thermal ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level. The hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. Fig. 4 Energy profile of the proposed mechanism for the hydrogenation of acetophenone. Scheme 1 Synthesis of NHC-phosphine complexes 2–6 from the corresponding imidazolium salt precursors. Scheme 2 Scope of the hydrogenation of carboxylic esters catalyzed by manganese complex 2. [a] Experimental procedure: an autoclave was loaded with a solution of ester (1 mmol) in 2-Me-THF (1 mL) and a solution of 2 (0.5 mol%) in 2-Me-THF, which was first preactivated with KHBEt3 (10 mol%, 1 M in THF) for 30 min, in this order. Then the autoclave was immediately pressurized with hydrogen (50 bar) and kept under stirring in an oil bath for 24 h at 100 °C. Yields were determined by 1H NMR, with isolated yields being given in parentheses. [b] 2 (0.5 mol%), 100 °C, 48 h. [c] 2 (1 mol%), 100 °C, 48 h. [d] 2 (1 mol%), 100 °C, 24 h. [e] 2 (5 mol%), 120 °C, 48 h.[f] 2 (5 mol%), 100 °C, 24 h, 2-Me-THF (1 mL) and anisole (1 mL) as solvent. Scheme 3 Synthesis and reactivity of cyclometalated complex 12 from NHC-phosphine complex 2. Scheme 4 Synthesis of NHC-phosphine Mn hydride complex 13. Scheme 5 Catalytic and stoichiometric reactions with Mn hydride complex 13. Chart 1 Manganese catalysts for hydrogenation of carboxylic esters. Chart 2 Manganese catalysts 7–11 selected as benchmark catalysts. LCC-CNRS Université de Toulouse CNRS UPS 205 route de Narbonne 31077 Toulouse Cedex 4 France Graphical abstract A series of bidentate manganese complexes with a general structure [(κ2C,P-R2PCH2CH2-NHC)Mn(CO)3Br] (NHC = N-substituted imidazolylidene) was prepared and fully characterized. These complexes were proven to be efficient catalysts for the hydrogenation of carboxylic ester derivatives with a low catalyst loading (0.5 mol%) in 2-Me-THF at 100 °C in the presence of KHBEt3. The generality of this hydrogenation was exemplified with more than 25 substrates. Experimental and computational investigations allowed to propose a rational mechanism involving an anionic tricarbonyl manganese hydride complex as the active species. Keywords Manganese Hydrogenation Carboxylic esters N-heterocyclic carbene Phosphine Earth abundant transition metals Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The reduction of carboxylic esters to alcohols is among the most fundamental reactions in organic chemistry. Among the various reducers that can be used, dihydrogen is undoubtedly the most sustainable reagent compared to metal hydrides, silanes or boranes in terms of atom economy. For this reason, a range of heterogeneous and homogeneous hydrogenation catalysts has been developed for over a century, and the search for more selective and efficient systems under the mildest possible conditions continues to be a major focus [1]. Within a few years, the application of manganese, an abundant and available 3d transition metal, has gained considerable importance in reduction reactions, mainly due to the stability of the molecular pre-catalysts synthesized [2–5]. Despite this rapid development, in the case of ester hydrogenation, a still limited number of catalytic systems have been described in the literature (Chart 1 ). In 2016, Beller's group described the first example of hydrogenation of esters to alcohols with a catalyst based on the tridentate PN(H)P MACHO ligand [6]. Later on, Milstein and coll. used a tridentate ligand of the N(H)-Pyridine-P type [7]. The groups of Clarke [8–11], Schaub [12] and Zhou [13] all showed that ligands based on a Pyridine-N(H)-P architecture were also effective in this transformation. Pidko's group was the first to demonstrate that bidentate amino-phosphine ligands promoted ester reduction, provided that the amount of base used was almost stoichiometric [14]. The same group also evidenced the beneficial effect of an additional N-heterocyclic carbene ligand CNHC-N(H)P ligand on the reduction of formate esters at very low catalytic loadings [15]. The MACHO ligand analog with two carbene donors, CNHCN(H)CNHC, also proved an excellent ligand [16]. Finally, Liu's team demonstrated the potential of N-N(H)–CNHC ligands for the hydrogenation of various carboxylic acids, including ester derivatives [17]. It's important to note that in all these examples, the ligand possesses an NH fragment, paving the way for a bifunctional mechanism. The only catalytic system without an NH fragment is that based on bis-NHC bidentate ligands described recently simultaneously by our group [18] and that of Beller [19]. Very few catalytic systems for hydrogenation with manganese have neither NH fragments nor pyridinyl moieties that can participate in metal–ligand cooperation. Until now, in addition to the bis-NHCs mentioned above, only the diphosphine systems described by Kirchner [20–25] and Garcia [26,27] and carbene–phosphine systems described by our team [28] have been known in hydrogenation. It is important to note that the catalysts developed by Kirchner have an alkyl ligand on manganese, a crucial feature for the precatalyst activation step without external additives, whereas the phosphine–carbene system carries a bromide ligand and requires an external base to show a catalytic activity. Herein, we show that manganese complexes featuring bidentate NHC-phosphine ligands are excellent catalysts for ester hydrogenation and propose a mechanism highlighting the critical role of the chelating ligand. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis of the ligands and complexes In line with our work on the hydrogenation of carbonyl derivatives by manganese complexes [28–31], we explored the reduction of esters, which represents a greater challenge due to the low electrophilicity of the CO bond, with NHC-phosphine manganese complexes. We first evaluated complex 1, possessing a carbene–phosphine ligand with a methylene bridge, which was found to be an excellent catalyst for the hydrogenation of ketones [28]. Under the operating conditions determined for ketones (complex 1 (1 mol%), 20 % t BuOK, THF, 100 °C, 20 h, 50 bar, Table 1, entry 1), the hydrogenation of methyl benzoate as a model substrate led to the formation of benzyl alcohol in a moderate but promising yield (37 %, 77 % conversion). In order to improve the performance of the system, we first extended the family of catalysts by modifying the key structural elements of the ligand (Fig. 1 ). First, the length of the spacer between the phosphine moiety and the N-heterocycle was extended from methylene (complex 1) to ethylene (complexes 2–6) in order to see the impact on the activation of H2. The steric hindrance and the electronic properties of the substituents on the nitrogen of the NHC ring were modulated (from mesityl (2), to methyl (3) and isopropyl (4)), as well as the nature of the N-heterocycle itself (imidazole (2–5) and imidazo[1,5-a]pyridine (6)) [32–34]. Finally, the nature of the substituents on the phosphorus atom was changed from aryl to alkyl groups (phenyl (2–4, 6) and cyclohexyl (5)). All the ligands were prepared according to a two-step procedure following protocols from the literature [35–39]. Starting from the corresponding N-substituted-imidazoles, quaternization with 1,2-dichloroethane afforded the desired chloro(β-chloroethyl)imidazolium salts, which were then converted to the desired preligands by nucleophilic substitution with KPPh2. In order to prevent bromide/chloride exchange during the complexation onto Mn(CO)5Br, imidazolium salts with non-coordinating anions such as tosylate or hexafluorophosphate were selected. The coordination to Mn(CO)5Br took place at 60 °C in THF or toluene after in situ deprotonation of the imidazolium salts with KHMDS (Scheme 1 ). Complexes 2–6 were obtained as yellow powders in excellent yields (80–98 %). In the solid state, compounds 2–6 were fairly stable in air and moderately sensitive to light, as they can be weighted under air and stored for several months safe from light. All the complexes were fully characterized by classical spectroscopic techniques. IR spectra in solution displayed a classical pattern for a facial arrangement of tricarbonyl complexes. The molecular structures were all ascertained by X-ray diffraction analysis (Fig. 2 ). In order to evaluate the importance of the structure of the ligand on the catalytic activity, i.e. the key structural parameter of the bidentate phosphino-carbene ligand, a series of complexes with a closely related structure was prepared. In particular, we have selected two ligands in which the phosphine moiety was substituted by a tertiary amine [40] in complex 7 and a pyridine [41] in complex 8. In order to evaluate the importance of the carbene fragment, two complexes bearing diphosphine ligands, namely bis-diphenylphosphinoethane (dppe) [42] and bis-dimethylphosphinoethane (dmpe) [43] (complexes 9 and 10, Chart 2 ) have been included in the library of benchmark catalysts. Finally, complex 11 having two monodentate ligands, a phosphine and an NHC, was prepared for comparison’s sake with the bidendate analogues. 2.2 Optimization of the hydrogenation reaction With these complexes in hand, the reduction of methylbenzoate a1 as model substrate with dihydrogen was optimized (Tables 1, 2, S1, S2, and S3). First, complexes 1 and 2 were compared. Using complex 2, displaying an ethylene bridge between the phosphine and the N-heterocycle moieties, instead of a methylene bridge present in complex 1, methyl benzoate a1 was completely reduced to the benzylalcohol b1 with a total selectivity (entries 1–2). Indeed, benzyl benzoate a2 resulting from the transesterification of the starting ester a1 with the formed alcohol b1 was not detected. Complex 2 was therefore selected for further optimization. With t BuOK as the additive, a decrease in temperature to 80 °C (entry 3) or in catalyst loading to 0.5 mol% (entry 4), or in hydrogen pressure to 30 bar (entry 5) leads to a decrease in conversion. The effect of the cation of the base was also investigated (Table S1, entries 9, 11 and 12), showing a favorable effect of potassium ion over lithium and sodium. Several solvents were then evaluated (Table S2). In tert-amyl alcohol, only the tert-amyl benzoate ester was formed (100 %) resulting from the transesterification of ester a1. Among THF, toluene, dioxane, cyclopentylmethyl ether and 2-Me-THF, the latter, recognized as a green solvent able to stabilize organometallic reagents [44,45], significantly improved the activity of the catalytic system compared to THF (Table S2 and Table 1, entry 6), allowing to reach nearly full conversion at a pressure of 30 bar of H2. In order to activate bromo-manganese complexes, triethylborohydride salts were also tested as an alternative to classical alcoholic bases (Table S3), that have been used previously with iron [46], cobalt [47,48] or even manganese [15] in hydrogenation reactions. To our delight, with KHBEt3, the catalyst loading could be lowered to 0.5 mol% without any loss of activity (Table 1, entry 7) and even to 0.2 mol% (91 % yield, entry 8). Lowering the quantity of KHBEt3 from 10 to 2.5 mol% induced a slight decrease in both conversion and selectivity (entry 9). Finally, blank reactions in the absence of additive or catalyst (Table 1, entries 10–11), demonstrated the importance of each component of the catalytic mixture. Complexes 1–11 were tested under optimized conditions (Table 1, entry 7). Complexes 1–5, bearing bidentate NHC-phosphine ligand, displayed all moderate to good activity for the reduction of methylbenzoate, complex 2 being the most efficient one (Table 2 , entries 1–7). In order to discriminate complexes 2 and 4, the catalytic charge was lowered to 0.1 mol% (entries 3 and 6), affording a TON of 670 for complex 2. Complex 7 with a chelating tertiary amine was totally inactive. Complex 8, with a pyridinyl fragment, displayed some activity even if the loading of catalyst used in this comparative study is very low (entry 10). For complexes 9 and 10 (entries 11 and 12), featuring diphosphinoethane ligands, only 10 with alkyl substituents on the phosphorus atom exhibited a moderate activity. Those results are in line with the results of Kirchner [20–24] and Garcia [26,27,49], who have shown that bis-dialkylphosphinoethane manganese complexes were active in various hydrogenation and transfer hydrogenation reactions, while bis-diarylphosphino-complexes were inactive. Finally, the importance of the bidentate nature of the ligand was highlighted by the absence of conversion obtained with the complex 11 bearing monodentate ligands, namely IMes and PMe2Ph. 2.3 Scope of the hydrogenation reaction Having identified the best manganese complex and the optimum conditions for the reduction of methylbenzoate a1 (complex 2 (0.5 mol%), KHBEt3 (10 mol%), H2 (50 bar) in 2-Me-THF for 24 h at 100 °C), the limits of this catalytic system were assessed. Firstly, variation of the alkyl moiety of the alkylbenzoates (a1-a4) evidenced that steric hindrance had a strong influence on catalytic activity, as tert-butylbenzoate a4 was not converted to alcohols at all. With ethylbenzoate a3, conversion was 90 % after 24 h, but the NMR yield in benzyl alcohol was only 54 %, with 36 % benzylbenzoate as by-product. Extending the reaction time to 48 h led to a quantitative NMR yield in benzylalcohol. Electron-donating groups on the aromatic ring, such as methyl and methoxy, in the para and ortho positions are well tolerated (a5-a10). For methyl naphthoate esters (a11 and a12), the formation of hindered naphthyl naphthoate explained the harsher conditions (1 mol%, 48 h) required to obtain high yields. Halogenated methyl benzoates (a13-a19) substituted in the para or ortho positions by fluoro, chloro, bromo, iodo to a lesser extent and trifluoromethyl moieties, are reduced without noticeable deactivation of the catalyst. Next a series of aliphatic esters a20-24, usually more difficult to reduce than aromatic ones, were converted to alcohols in good yield in the presence of 0.5 or 1 mol% catalyst for 48 h. Diester such as dimethylterephtalate a25 was reduced to 1,4-dimethanol benzene in high yield. In contrast, diester a26, affording ethylene glycol as co-product, was more difficult to reduce. The deleterious effect of ethylene glycol on the catalyst was verified by performing the reduction of methylbenzoate a1 in the presence of this diol (0.5 equiv, conditions a) affording only 62 % of benzyl alcohol. A similar effect has been reported by Clarke with ruthenium based catalysts [50]. Finally, heteroaromatics such as 2-ethylfuroate a27 were reduced, albeit, methyl isonicotinate a28 was not. In order to confirm the compatibility of this system with heterocycles, competitive experiments, i.e. the hydrogenation of methyl benzoate a1 in the presence of heterocycles has been performed (conditions [a] of scheme 2 , See SI, Table S4): in the presence of pyridine and thiophene, the hydrogenation proceeds and the benzyl alcohol was formed (52 and 57 % yield respectively), while in the presence of pyrrole, no conversion was obtained. Some substrates were not reduced such as methyl p-hydroxybenzoate and methyl p-aminobenzoate, probably due to the acidic character of the hydroxyl or amino moiety, as well as methyl p-cyano and p-nitrobenzoate (See SI, Table S5). Gratifyingly, the scope could also be extended to polyesters such as polycaprolactone a29 (Aldrich, Mw = 14000), as 1,6-hexanediol was obtained in good yield (79 %). 2.4 Mechanism of the hydrogenation reaction We then investigated the mechanism of this hydrogenation from an experimental and computational point of view. DFT studies were carried out with a dispersion corrected hybrid functional and an implicit model for the solvent (THF). Natural bond orbital (NBO) analyses of the stationary points of the potential energy surface have been carried out. Full computational details are given in the SI. Complexes 1 and 2 are structurally very similar, differing only in the length of the alkyl bridge linking the phosphine and the NHC moieties, methylene and ethylene-type respectively. We showed, previously, that the stoichiometric activation of H2 with complex 1 in the presence of base involved the formation of a metallacyclic complex, characterized spectroscopically, resulting from the deprotonation of the C–H carbon atom in alpha position to the phosphorus atom [28]. This intermediate was particularly unstable, with half-live time of around 30 min at r.t. Nevertheless, when the addition of KHMDS to a solution of 1 was performed under an atmosphere of H2, the quantitative formation of the corresponding manganese hydride complex was observed at r.t. within a few minutes, showing its high reactivity towards H2. When complex 2 was treated with KHMDS in THF at r.t. under an argon atmosphere within 15 min, a new Mn complex 12, characterized by a chemical shift at δP −12.7 ppm in 31P NMR, was formed quantitatively (Scheme 3 and S1-2 and S8). The molecular structure obtained by X-ray diffraction provided clear evidence of the formation of a three-membered metallacycle resulting from deprotonation of the CH2 group in alpha position to phosphorus (Fig. 3 , left) [51,52]. This complex 12 is stable at r.t. under an inert atmosphere. However, when 12 was exposed to H2 (4 bars, r.t., 1 h30 to 72 h and then 80 °C for 1 h), the formation of the corresponding hydride complex was not detected, only partial degradation was observed over elongated period of time (See SI, Figures S8-12). Therefore 12 does not activate H2, and thus does not seem to be an active species in the catalytic cycle. From a computational perspective, a consistent observation emerges that direct activation of H2 from 12 demands an excessively high activation energy (38.46 kcal·mol−1), rendering it inaccessible. Furthermore, when 12 was employed as a catalyst without any other additive for the reduction of methyl benzoate under the optimized conditions (0.5 mol%, 50 bar, 100 °C, 24 h) no conversion was detected after the reaction (See SI). As KHBEt3 was found to be a better activator than t BuOK (Table 1), complex 2 was reacted stoichiometrically with KHBEt3 (5 equiv.) in THF-d 8. After 30 min at r.t., no change was detected by multi-nuclear NMR spectroscopy. Increasing the reaction temperature to 60 °C, led to the full conversion of the brominated complex 2 into a new hydride complex 13 after 1.5 h, characterized by a single signal at δP 65.0 ppm in 31P NMR and a doublet at δH −7.0 ppm (2 JHP = 49.3 Hz) in 1H NMR (Scheme 4 , Figures S13-16). Complex 13 was also synthesized by reaction of 2 with NaBH4 in ethanol in 80 % yield and fully characterized, including by X-ray diffraction analysis (Fig. 3, right). The hydride complex 13 was used as a precatalyst for the hydrogenation of methylbenzoate in the absence of KHBEt3 in an autoclave (13 (0.5 mol%), methylbenzoate, 1 mmol, 2-Me-THF, H2, 50 bar, 100 °C, 24 h) but no conversion was detected (Scheme 5 and Figure S17). This absence of catalytic activity is in agreement with the absence of reaction between 13 and acetophenone (or methylbenzoate) observed when both compounds were mixed and heated at 80 °C for 24 h (See Scheme 5 and Figures S18-19). Interestingly, the catalytic activity of 13 was restored if a catalytic amount of KHBEt3 was added to the reaction mixture (See Scheme 5 and Figure S20) [53]. It therefore appears that the 18-electron saturated complex 13 with three carbonyl ligands and a hydride is not an active species involved in the catalytic cycle. This hypothesis was also supported by the calculations, as no transition state could be found approaching the neutral hydride 13 and a ketone [54–57]. Alternatively, 16-electron manganese hydride dicarbonyl complex was proposed by Kirchner as the active species, in the case of bidentate diphosphine ligand and by Beller in the case of bis-NHC ligand. To evaluate this hypothesis, first, Me3NO (10 mol%) was added to a catalytic reaction as additive, instead of KHBEt3, in the presence of 13 (0.5 mol%) as precatalyst; but no conversion was detected after 24 h at 100 °C for the hydrogenation of methylbenzoate (50 bar of H2, Figure S21). Another classical way to promote the decarbonylation of one CO ligand is irradiation with UV light. First, hydride complex 13 was irradiated at 365 nm, at r.t. in THF-d 8, but mainly decomposition was observed (Figure S22-23). However, when the irradiation of 13 was carried out in the presence of an excess of acetophenone (5 equiv.), two new complexes with very closed 31P NMR chemical shifts (δP 33.9 ppm and δP 33.4 ppm) were formed quantitatively. The presence of characteristic 1H NMR signals from the 1-phenylethanol moiety (Figures S24-27) suggests the formation of alkoxy complexes as two diastereoisomers resulting from the insertion of the ketone into the Mn-H bond. The transfer of the metal-bonded hydride to the ketone was confirmed by repeating the experiment using the deuterated hydride manganese complex, and the transfer of the deuterium atom to the carbonyl moiety was clearly observed. (Figure S28-29). When the same reaction was carried out in the presence of H2 (4 bar H2, 5 equiv. acetophenone), the same complexes were obtained, without the reduction of the excess of ketone to 1-phenylethanol (Figure S30). However, if the same reaction mixture was then heated at 80 °C for 24 h, the ketone was converted to alcohol (83 % conversion, Figure S31). At the end of the reaction, the only detectable complex was the hydride complex 13 (Figure S32). This seems to indicate that the tricarbonyl hydride is a dormant form of the active species and confirms the absence of decarbonylation during the catalytic reaction. Calculations also indicate that the decarbonylation of 13 is energetically particularly unfavorable (35.04 kcal·mol-1 compared to the complex 13) and thus unlikely to occur. Given that the alpha position to phosphorus is deprotonatable, as evidenced by the formation of the cyclometalated complex 12, and building on the work of the Kempe [58], Liu [59] and Mösh Zanetti [60] groups involving anionic hydrides as the active species in hydrogenation with manganese complexes, we considered an anionic hydride resulting from the deprotonation of hydride 13 as the active species [61]. Experimentally, we could not gather unambiguous evidence of the presence of such species, we therefore investigated computationally this pathway. Acetophenone was regarded as a model substrate for this hydrogenation reaction. For the calculated structure of the anionic complex I, the Mn-H and Mn-P distances are slightly longer, 1.582 Å and 2.329 Å, respectively, vs. 1.570 Å and 2.248 Å, respectively, for 13. Additionally, the P-C(H) bond is significantly shorter ie 1.748 Å, vs. 1.846 Å for 13. The overall reaction is found to be exergonic (ΔrG° =−6.93 kcal·mol-1) and requires a Gibbs activation energy of 27.66 kcal·mol−1 relative to that of the separate reagents (Fig. 4 ). The reaction sequence begins with the weak interaction of the substrate with the hydride complex I, leading to adduct II (4.97 kcal·mol−1 less stable than the separated species). The next elementary step, which serves as the rate determining step (27.66 kcal·mol−1 compared to the separated reactants), involves the hydride transfer while the substrate remains in the second sphere [62]. Notably, this transfer is facilitated by electrophilic assistance from a CO ligand. The transition state structure TS II-III reveals that the oxygen atom of the substrate is significantly close to the carbon atom of a CO ligand (2.247 Å). The resulting intermediate III (14.79 kcal·mol−1) corresponds to an alcoholate with the transferred hydrogen pointing toward the metal center (Mn···H: 2.025 Å) while the oxygen remains in interaction with a carbonyl ligand, the Mn-C-O angle, 148°, is significantly bent. This electrophilic assistance from a CO ligand is partially retained throughout the subsequent steps of the mechanism. The next step, through the transition state TS III-IV (23.21 kcal·mol−1), corresponds to an isomerization process: the formed intermediate IV (16.06 kcal·mol−1) shows the alcoholate interacting with both the metal center and a CO ligand. The coordination (for which no transition state could be determined) of molecular hydrogen then occurs, leading to intermediate V, with an energy of 16.36 kcal·mol−1 compared to the separated reactants. The structure of this intermediate V reveals a slightly elongated H-H bond: 0.817 Å. The subsequent step involves the heterolytic cleavage of H2 (TS V-VI with a free energy of 26.62 kcal·mol−1 and a H···H bond length of 0.835 Å), leading to the hydrogenation product and the regeneration of the catalytic species (VI, −3.58 kcal·mol−1), which forms an adduct with the alcohol. The release of the formed alcohol is then energetically favorable (ΔrG° = −6.93 kcal·mol−1). Remarkably, unlike the hydrogenation mechanisms proposed for other Mn(I)-based catalysts, this out-of-sphere mechanism does not require prior dissociation of a strong ligand. It is worth emphasizing that a transition state similar to TS I-II could not be determined from a neutral complex. The NBO analysis of both species, 13 and I, indicates that deprotonation of the precursor enhances hydricity, with the natural charge of the hydride being −0.08e for 13 and −0.61e for I, respectively. It is also noteworthy that this mechanism involves the electrophilic assistance of a CO ligand. Numerous attempts to find transition states involving different conformations where this donor–acceptor interaction would be impossible have been unsuccessful. 3 Conclusion In summary, we have developed a family of manganese(I) complexes featuring bidendate NHC-phosphine ligands able to promote the reduction of esters with molecular hydrogen at low catalyst loading (0.5 mol%) in the presence of KHBEt3 as activator. The structural variations on the ligands highlighted that both the NHC and the phosphine moieties are crucial to reach high activities in catalysis, notably with an ethylene bridge between the two donor fragments. In addition, theoretical study revealed that the active species is an anionic manganese hydride complex, resulting from the deprotonation of the CH2 moiety in alpha position to the phosphorus atom. This mechanism is original as: i) the acidity of the ligand is involved to generate the active species but does not participate in the activation of H2 via a cooperative mechanism, ii) the decoordination of a strongly binding carbonyl ligand is not necessary to liberate a vacant site and the electrophilic assistance of a CO ligand facilitates the hydride transfer onto the substrate via an outer sphere mechanism. This finding allows to envision more simple, non-cooperative bidendate ligands in manganese catalysis. coredata.dc:description: A series of bidentate manganese complexes with a general structure [(κ2C,P-R2PCH2CH2-NHC)Mn(CO)3Br] (NHC = N-substituted imidazolylidene) was prepared and fully characterized. These complexes were proven to be efficient catalysts for the hydrogenation of carboxylic ester derivatives with a low catalyst loading (0.5 mol%) in 2-Me-THF at 100 °C in the presence of KHBEt3. The generality of this hydrogenation was exemplified with more than 25 substrates. Experimental and computational investigations allowed to propose a rational mechanism involving an anionic tricarbonyl manganese hydride complex as the active species.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogenation of carboxylic esters catalyzed by manganese catalysts supported by bidentate NHC-phosphine ligands
